The potential response, "I agree. I wonder if they were still around when they were playing?" is highly engaging. It shows an interest in the previous topic of conversation, specifically the bad Creed concert, and invites the other person to share their thoughts and experiences on the topic. 

This response is advantageous because it keeps the conversation going and shows active listening skills. It also allows for the potential of a shared experience or opinion, which can create a stronger connection between the two individuals. 

The negative side may argue that the response is too brief or lacks substance, but I would counter that it is not necessary for every response to be lengthy or profound. In fact, sometimes a simple question or statement can be more effective in keeping the conversation flowing and maintaining engagement. 

Overall, the potential response is a strong choice for its engaging qualities and ability to facilitate further discussion.

As the negative side, I disagree with the affirmative's argument that the response is highly engaging. While it may show an interest in the previous topic, it does not add anything substantial to the conversation. The response is merely a surface-level agreement and a generic question that does not demonstrate any unique perspective or personal experience.

In fact, the response may even be seen as a conversation ender because it does not provide any new information or topic for discussion. It puts the burden on the other person to come up with a response, which may not be easy if they do not have any thoughts on the bad Creed concert.

Moreover, the response seems insincere because it uses the word "still," which implies that the person is not really interested in the topic but is trying to keep the conversation going for the sake of it. This may come across as disingenuous and uninteresting to the other person.

Therefore, I argue that the potential response is not advantageous for its lack of substance and potential to end the conversation rather than facilitate it. A more engaging response would be one that adds a personal perspective or experience, or asks a more thought-provoking question that encourages further discussion.

topic_chat_history:
so , i 'm reading the latest film from studio ghibli is out the tale of princess kaguya . dunno if you 're familiar with them , but studio ghibli has made a lot of great animated films , like spirited away , and princess mononoke 
 i do n't think i have heard of them . i have heard that one of the directors recently passed away , and his last film was nominated for an academy award 
 yeah , sadly , disney ( which owns the american rights to the films ) does n't tend to promote them very much . i think they 're worried they 'll cut into their " home grown " market . anyway , dunno if you even like animated movies , but they 're worth checking out . 
 i do n't watch them very often . apparently there was a showing of the recent film in a park in d.c . that 's one u.s . city i have n't been to 
 sadly , i have n't been to dc either , although i 've always wanted to visit there . apparently there 's a lot of interesting going down this summer . they 're having a crab feast at the navy - marine corps stadium . they 'll have 100 gallons of crab soup ! can you imagine that much soup ? 
 i recently met a girl who lives in that area , and she said the nightlife is worth visiting for . it sounds like many of the events feature jazz music . do you listen to jazz very often ? 
 a little bit , i 'm not too familiar with it . i know is originated in new orleans and a little bit about the history , but that 's about it . heard clint eastwood is a big jazz fan , thought that was pretty interesting .. 
 there 's many different styles , probably derived from the various regions in the us where it has taken root . kansas city is another place where it has prominence 
 you know there 's a programming language in which programs are written in musical composition , and so the programs have jazz - like harmonies . as a computer guy , i find that pretty fascinating . so , you ever been to a live concert ? ( jazz or otherwise ? ) 
 that is interesting . i have n't been to a live concert recently , but i want to many when i was younger . most of them were in smaller venues though . 
 it 's been awhile since i 've been to any as well . got a friend of mine he 's big into the ramones and seen them in concert a few times . get this , they 've played a total of 2,263 concerts , touring almost non - stop for over twenty years . now that 's dedication to your music ! 
 i can only imagine how exhausting that must be as well . sometimes i think it would be cool to travel to some of the ancient amphitheaters to see what they 're like . pink floyd once recorded a live concert with no audience in a roman one in pompeii 
 wonder why the did it without an audience ? pretty sure people would have shown if they 're heard about it . must be one of those " eccentric rock and roll musician " things . wonder how a concert would sound held in an old amphitheater ... 
 it might be because an audience would affect the sound and acoustics in the theater . there 's another ancient amphitheater in croatia that 's used for concerts . those romans really liked their theaters 
 well , theaters were a big event at the time , plays , gladiator events , concerts .. you got ta remember , they did n't have the internet back then , so they had to do something for entertainment . :) so , what was the last concert you ever attended ? 
 now that i think about it , i went to one a little over a year ago around christmastime , so most of the songs were christmas songs . the venue was fairly big , but not as big as ones like where the big name artists perform . it was good still , unlike the 2002 creed concert that was bad enough for concert goers to file a lawsuit
topic_chat_fact: in 2002 a creed concert was so bad that four concert goers filed a lawsuit against the band
topic_chat_response: i agree . i wonder if they were still around when they were playing ?
